title: On 1 October 2019, how many countries will be on Russia's food embargo list?
preds: Updating for passage of time, not expecting any changes in the remaining 4 days.  One interesting aspect that I had overlooked so far: if Brexit had gone to the original schedule and not been postponed, Russia would have needed to update their list which so far treats the EU member countries as a bloc - I am pretty sure a brexited UK would have been added to the emmbargo list, but nevertheless, something I had not thought about.
Not likely to start paring down the list just yet....
Putin extended the embargo until the end of 2019 for most countries and recently extended it til the end of 2020 for EU countries.

Russia has trust issues with the US and Canada thus ruling out zero (0). Back in 2014 ( https://ec.europa.eu/food/safety/international_affairs/eu_russia/russian_import_ban_eu_products_en ) Russia banned food imports from the EU and that has remained officially in effect despite a strong black market. The EU presently has 28 countries (although with UK Brexit it might be 27 but the UK block from West would remain).  You then take into account island countries and  Latin American countries such as Colombia, Argentina, Brazil and Peru. However Asia and Africa would remain open. Non EU Eastern European countries and Armenia get much more complicated. Then when looking at places such as Iran and other countries, rivalries for trade are starting to develop between China and Russia while the Middle East with places such as Afghanistan have a complicated relationship with Russia.

On 12 July 2018 the validity of the embargo was further prolonged until 31 December 2019 by the Presidential Decree No. 420     Original Decree No. 420
https://ec.europa.eu/food/safety/international_affairs/eu_russia/russian_import_ban_eu_products_en Russia: Russia Extended Food Import Ban through End 2019
https://www.fas.usda.gov/data/russia-russia-extended-food-import-ban-through-end-2019 The list won't change and unless Western sanctions are lifted Putin will not remove his. This might continue on for a year or more.

because there are many coutries have problem in there food prodoction and there are many political reasons to list countries in embargo

It's hard to make a final decision to how many or who exactly will it be, but I see that Russia just as us doesnt like to be led by the nose, they have very small patience, so mostly any of russias old allies in the eastern Europe will be rid of (except Belarus), middle east will be a focus on relationship improvement for many delicate oil deals, China will be a passive battle, they will mostly team up and go against us, that could also include Canada, as it decided to tie itself with us ordeal in Chinese company affair of arresting the Huawei representative, and it probably won't stop from there, it will also most likely include uk
No reason not to embargo a country as a symbolic gesture while still importing the products you need.
Money and greed talks louder than politicians

The embargo was imposed in retaliation for sanctions over Crimea. Since it is unlikely that additional countries will impose sanctions on Russia over the annexation of Crimea this year, I think the odds of an increase beyond 37 is small. My forecast of 26% for a decrease of one is based on the possibility that Brexit will occur before October and Russia will not impose the embargo separately on Britain.
Because of weird stuff happening in my life, I just want some peace just, peace

An easy one. The question would there be any reduction in sanctions against Russia by the end of the year. The answer is No. There is a minimal chance that new regime in Ukraine may change the stance but still full reversal by the end of the 2019 is negligibly small.
Russia are seeking to expand embargos, not reduce them. [updated forecast]
Going up a couple points to stay above the consensus.
I don't see any progress in the stalemate over the invasion and annexation of Crimea and continued occupation of Eastern Ukraine, hence no decrease in the 37.

PM Medvedev bans imports of several Ukrainian goods to Russia Earlier, the Ukrainian government extended embargo on food imports from Russia until 2020 The government noted that Russia might decide to cancel the introduction of special economic measures, if Ukraine abolishes the restrictive measures introduced earlier in relation to specific Russian goods. http://tass.com/economy/1038507 Currently tensions are likely to increase till 2020. Until countries start climbing down from their initial positions.  5 big predictions for Russia’s food & drink sector

Sanctions remain in place

This isn’t so much a prediction as a guarantee. Russia’s ongoing embargo on imported produce from the US, EU, Australia, Canada, and Norway, remains in place until the end of 2019. 

We are now nearly five years down the line since Russia first banned imported goods from the aforementioned countries. That means supplies of key foodstuffs, like meat, fruits and vegetables, and dairy products, are still banned from entering Russia from those source markets.

There are still significant product groups in affected countries that can still be exported to Russia, so the door is not completely closed. 

But the fact remains: the Russian embargo will not be lifted in 2019. 
https://www.world-food.ru/en-GB/press/news/Russia-food-drink-2019-5-predictions.aspx

Some countries will change leadership that will remove sanctions. President Trump is trying to remove sanctions but in the end, I believe Russia will continue to piss off more countries as the lack of US response is Just emboldening President Putin.

Sanctions have been extended until the end of 2019: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/770912
I see a small chance that sanctions will be lifted from individual countries, but not from the EU who I would assume to be treated en bloc.
No changes to a better to expect.
There doesn't seem to be any movement reducing tensions that would cause Russia to take countries off the list.
Shifting a bit toward 37 as it seems relations between Russia and the West are not improving anytime soon.

Doing fairly well from it as allowed agriculture to flourish a bit. Now exporting grain and beef, so likely to want to continue unless EU decide to take down sanctions which is highly unlikely. Might try to pick out individual countries in EU which are more allied and restart trade on food.

The underlying motivation for these embargoes - retaliation against sanction participants and their trade partners - seems unlikely to change significantly before the end of 2019. At the moment it seems most likely that the UK will remain on, or be re-added to, the list post-Brexit.  Russia has the ability to address domestic shortfalls by fiddling with product exemptions (as it has already done with various fish fry, seeds, supplement, baby food inputs etc) - this allows Russia significant flexibility to chip away at the embargo without needing to remove entire countries from the list.  Various news outlets have reported that the embargo has already been formally extended to the end of 2019 though the European Commission has not (yet) reported this or posted a translation on their website, as they have done with previous extensions.  From the drafting of the original decree (at least per the EC translation) and the fact that the product list can be and has been modified, I assume that Russia is still able to modify the country list as it sees fit even after a formal extension decree has been signed. Reserving a 1% chance of some form of rapprochement with one of the embargoed countries before the end of 2019, leading to its removal from the list. https://uk.reuters.com/article/russia-eu-sanctions/russia-extends-ban-on-some-eu-food-imports-until-dec-312019-idUKR4N1U0020
https://ec.europa.eu/food/safety/international_affairs/eu_russia/russian_import_ban_eu_products_en

In September 2018, the improvement in the attitude of the inhabitants of Russia to Western countries, which we celebrated in the spring of 2018, ceased. Since 2017, the “ratio index” values ​​for the United States or the EU, for Ukraine, ranged from 60 to 100 points, while in the period 2014-2016 they varied from 40 to 80. The higher the index value, the favorable attitude towards the country. But, even with the growth of positive attitudes in this period, in the Russian public opinion, beginning in the winter of 2014, negative perceptions of Western countries prevailed (as the sum of answers “mostly bad” and “very bad”). The positive attitude of Russians towards China remains unchanged.
https://www.levada.ru/2018/10/16/otnoshenie-k-stranam-2/

EU Ministers Approve New Chemical-Weapons Sanctions Regime
https://www.rferl.org/a/eu-ministers-approve-new-chemical-weapons-sanctions-regime/29544273.html
BRUSSELS -- EU foreign ministers have approved a new sanctions regime targeting people and entities using chemical weapons all around the world. The October 15 decision will allow the European Union to impose asset freezes and visa bans on people and entities for the development and use of chemical weapons, regardless of their nationality and location. EU individuals and entities are also not allowed to make funds available to those listed. The move follows repeated accusations of the use of chemical weapons by President Bashar al-Assad's regime in Syria and the poisoning of the Russian double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in the English city of Salisbury in March, which London has blamed on the Russian government.
It was at 37 when I first started research

I am confused why all jump into 37+ 
(but NONE linked a list with all affected countries)  my source says 36: 
http://country.eiu.com/article.aspx?articleid=1574372141&Country=Albania&topic=Economy&subtopic=Forecast&subsubtopic=External+sector&u=1&pid=1377014321&oid=1377014321&uid=1

Russia has extended the ban [1] until December 31, 2019. The ban looks permanent while the West continues to impose sanctions on Russia for its "annexation" of Crimea. It makes strategic sense for Russia (or any country for that matter) to grow its own food when there is tension with its neighbours. [1] https://theglobepost.com/2018/07/12/russia-western-food-embargo/

In 2018, the Russian minister of agriculture said "We hope that the food embargo will further stimulate the production and not be limited to 2018. We expect the boycott to remain in force until 2020." That in itself is enough to say that the embargo will last till at least 2019, but the major reason I am forecasting 80% for 37 or more countries to be in the embargo by Oct 2019 is because of the EU and constant instability between the US and Russia.   The EU which makes up the majority of the countries in the boycott has recently extended sanctions till January 2019 causing instability in an already unstable relationship. It is likely the sanctions will be extended longer causing the boycott to continue its term till 2020, especially as the relationship continues to worsen over the Russian spy poisoning and other current affairs. As for the other countries, they will stay in the boycott because of the (as Moscow stated) "degree of involvement of these countries in the sanctions regime."  In the chance that the EU ends sanctions (see Macron statement on "EU to have strategic relationship with...Russia that brings stability"), I have forecasted 20% between 1 and 31 countries being in the boycott because US-Russia relations are so unstable (with sanctions, etc) at the moment that the US will most likely continue to be boycotted against.  Overall, the boycott has been ongoing since 2014. It would take major steps forward for the boycott and sanctions to be removed, and Russia is claiming that the ban has stimulated branches of agroindustry further proving that the ban will most likely stay till at least October 2019.  Sources: 
www.yahoo.com/news/russia-slaps-food-embargo-more-european-countries-15062238.html

The embargo has officially been extended thru the end of 2019, so unless there are new exemptions, it will continue to affect at least 37 countries. https://theglobepost.com/2018/07/12/russia-western-food-embargo/

The current state of the Russian food infrastructure seem terrible, making the sanctions very costly for Russia, incentivizing Russia to stop the embargo. Furthemore the internatinal scene seem to be very fluid right now, anything could happen, including Russia adding more countries to the list.  Anything could happen, but most likely nothing will change.

Either the sanctions more or less unwind entirely due to either a US-led relaxation or an EU mutiny from the currently right-leaning states (Greece, Austria, and others), or I think it stays at 37. Given that the EU voted unanimously only 2 days ago to extend santions to Jan2019, I think there's a good chance we see these counter-sanctions get extended well into 2019.

At this stage, I'm approaching this question broadly. Will the sanctions increase or decrease? After the Salisbury attack, it seems unlikely that they will decrease, yet the integration of Russia into a global recreational event (world cup) has me believe that tensions are waning somewhat. For any but "37 or more" to be correct, the sanctions would need to decrease, but this hasn't happened since they were imposed.
Doesn't seem like Putina the Shirtless Ballerina really trusts Austria or Italy. Been too optimistic, so just going to stick it all on 37+

http://thehill.com/opinion/international/391588-support-for-russia-sanctions-crumbling-in-the-west Every day Trump is switching gears, so he could easily back down from Russian sanctions.  After all, they were best buds during Trump's campaign.  Also, Trump is infuriating Europeans on trade, and in general on everything, driving them closer to Russia.  But pure inertia weighs in favor of some weight in maintaining the 37+ countries.  After all, we've already made it several years, why not a few more?  Russian culture takes pride in being "hardy," as well, so as long as the West is a scapegoat, there's political cover for hurting themselves while reciprocating the sanctions.  Russia's been getting bailed out recently by higher oil prices, after all, and been increasing their oil exports.
